i am sending prop to child componet to opne the model how do i do that close tha modal in child component
1 / 1

To close a modal in a child component when a prop is passed from the parent component, you can create a state variable in the child component to control the visibility of the modal. Then, you can set the state variable to false in a function that is triggered by the prop passed from the parent component.

Here is an example:

javascript
// Parent Component
import { useState } from 'react';
import ChildComponent from './ChildComponent';

function ParentComponent() {
  const [showModal, setShowModal] = useState(false);

  const openModal = () => {
    setShowModal(true);
  }

  const closeModal = () => {
    setShowModal(false);
  }

  return (
    <>
      <button onClick={openModal}>Open Modal</button>
      <ChildComponent showModal={showModal} closeModal={closeModal} />
    </>
  );
}

// Child Component
import { useState, useEffect } from 'react';

function ChildComponent(props) {
  const [showModal, setShowModal] = useState(false);

  useEffect(() => {
    setShowModal(props.showModal);
  }, [props.showModal]);

  const handleClose = () => {
    setShowModal(false);
    props.closeModal();
  }

  return (
    <>
      {showModal &&
        <div className="modal">
          <div className="modal-content">
            <button onClick={handleClose}>Close Modal</button>
          </div>
        </div>
      }
    </>
  );
}

In this example, the ParentComponent renders a button to open the modal and passes two functions openModal and closeModal as props to the ChildComponent. The ChildComponent receives these functions as props and stores them in its own state.

When the showModal prop passed from the parent component changes, the useEffect hook in the ChildComponent updates the state of showModal to match the prop value.

The handleClose function is triggered when the user clicks the "Close Modal" button in the ChildComponent. This function first sets the state of showModal to false and then calls the closeModal function passed as a prop from the ParentComponent, which closes the modal.

how to pass function as props

To pass a function as a prop in React, you can simply pass the function as a value to the prop key in the parent component, and then use it as a callback in the child component. Here's an example:

Parent Component:

javascript
function ParentComponent() {
  const handleButtonClick = () => {
    console.log("Button clicked");
  };

  return (
    <div>
      <ChildComponent onButtonClick={handleButtonClick} />
    </div>
  );
}

Child Component:

javascript

  const { onButtonClick } = props;

  return (
    <div>
      <button onClick={onButtonClick}>Click me!</button>
    </div>
  );
}

In this example, we pass the handleButtonClick function as a prop to the ChildComponent by setting it to the onButtonClick prop key. Then, we destructure the onButtonClick prop in the child component and use it as a callback for the onClick event of the button.

.toDataURL
1 / 1

.toDataURL() is a method available on HTMLCanvasElement and is used to convert the contents of a canvas to a data URL. A data URL is a string that represents the contents of a file or resource as a base64-encoded string.

For example, if you have an image in a canvas and you want to save it or send it to a server, you can use .toDataURL() to convert the image to a data URL that can be used in a <img> tag or sent as part of an HTTP request. The data URL starts with "data:" followed by a MIME type (e.g. "image/png" for a PNG image) and then a base64-encoded string representing the contents of the file.

In order to change the state of the parent component from the child component, you can pass a function as a prop to the child component, which can then be called from the child component to change the state in the parent component.

For example, in the parent component, you can define a function called setShowModal that updates the showModal state:

javascript
function App() {
  const [showModal, setShowModal] = useState(false);

  return (
    <div>
      <button onClick={() => setShowModal(true)}>Open Modal</button>
      <Modal showModal={showModal} setShowModal={setShowModal} />
    </div>
  );
}

Then, in the child component Modal, you can call the setShowModal function to update the showModal state in the parent component:

javascript
function Modal(props) {
  const handleCloseModal = () => {
    props.setShowModal(false);
  };

  return (
    <div>
      {props.showModal && (
        <div>
          <h1>Modal</h1>
          <button onClick={handleCloseModal}>Close Modal</button>
        </div>
      )}
    </div>
  );
}

In the Modal component, the handleCloseModal function is called when the "Close Modal" button is clicked, which in turn calls the setShowModal function passed down from the parent component to update the showModal state in the parent component.

how to console.log() in react mounted hook
1 / 1

In React, you can use the useEffect hook to log something to the console when the component mounts. Here's an example:

javascript
import React, { useEffect } from 'react';

function MyComponent() {
  useEffect(() => {
    console.log('Component mounted');
  }, []);

  return (
    <div>
      {/* component content */}
    </div>
  );
}

In this example, the useEffect hook is used to execute a function when the component mounts. The second argument [] ensures that the function is only executed once (when the component mounts) and not on every re-render. In this case, the function simply logs a message to the console.

If you're passing a state-changing function as a prop to a child component, make sure that you're actually calling that function in the child component when you need to update the state.

Here's an example of how to pass a state-changing function as a prop to a child component:

javascript
// Parent component
function ParentComponent() {
  const [count, setCount] = useState(0);

  function incrementCount() {
    setCount(count + 1);
  }

  return (
    <div>
      <ChildComponent onIncrement={incrementCount} />
      <p>Count: {count}</p>
    </div>
  );
}

// Child component
function ChildComponent(props) {
  function handleClick() {
    props.onIncrement();
  }

  return (
    <button onClick={handleClick}>Increment count</button>
  );
}

In this example, ParentComponent passes incrementCount function as onIncrement prop to ChildComponent. ChildComponent calls this function when the button is clicked, which updates the state in ParentComponent. Make sure you're following a similar pattern in your code.

javascript

import ChildComponent from "./ChildComponent";

  const [count, setCount] = useState(0);

  function incrementCount() {
    setCount(count + 1);
  }

  return (
    <div>
      <ChildComponent handleClick={incrementCount} />
      <p>Count: {count}</p>
    </div>
  );
}

function ChildComponent(props) {
  function handleClick() {
    props.handleClick();
  }

  return (
    <div>
      <button onClick={handleClick}>Increment Count</button>
    </div>
  );
}

export default ChildComponent;

In this example, the ParentComponent has a state variable count and a function incrementCount that changes the value of count. The incrementCount function is passed to the ChildComponent as a prop called handleClick.

The ChildComponent has a button that, when clicked, calls the handleClick function passed to it as a prop. This in turn calls the incrementCount function in the ParentComponent, which changes the value of count and causes the ParentComponent to re-render with the updated count value.

To show the ImageCropper component on parent click, you can define a state in the parent component and pass it to the ImageCropper component as a prop. jsx

import ImageCropper from "./ImageCropper";

  const [showCropper, setShowCropper] = useState(false);

  const handleClick = () => {
    setShowCropper(true);
  };

  const handleCloseModal = () => {
    setShowCropper(false);
  };

  return (
    <div>
      <button onClick={handleClick}>Open Cropper</button>

        <ImageCropper
          showModal={showCropper}
          onHandleSave={(data) => console.log(data)}
          handleCloseModal={handleCloseModal}
        />
      )}
    </div>
  );
}

In this example, we have defined a state called showCropper in the parent component with an initial value of false. On the click of the button, we set the showCropper state to true, which will cause the ImageCropper component to be rendered with the prop showModal set to true. When the user clicks the cancel button in the ImageCropper component, we call the handleCloseModal function passed as a prop, which will set the showCropper state back to false and hide the ImageCropper component.

  const showCropperModal = (e) => {
    setCropper(true);
    e.stopPropagation();
  };

  const closeCropperModal = () => {
    setCropper(false);
  };

    <div>
      <div
        style={{

          border: "1px solid gainsboro",
          marginTop: "20px",
          marginLeft: "auto",
          marginRight: "auto",
          cursor: "pointer",
        }}
        onClick={showCropperModal}
      >
        <img src={croppedImage ? croppedImage : ""}></img>
      </div>
      <ImageCropper
        showModal={cropper}
        onHandleSave={getCroppedImage}
        handleCloseModal={closeCropperModal}
      />
    </div>
  );
}

import ReactCrop from "react-image-crop";
import "react-image-crop/dist/ReactCrop.css";
import { Modal } from "antd";

export default function ImageCropper({
  showModal,
  onHandleSave,
  handleCloseModal,
}) {
  const [crop, setCrop] = useState({ unit: "%", width: 30, aspect: 16 / 9 });

  const getCroppedImg = (image, crop, fileName) => {
    const canvas = document.createElement("canvas");
    const scaleX = image.naturalWidth / image.width;
    const scaleY = image.naturalHeight / image.height;
    canvas.width = crop.width * scaleX;
    canvas.height = crop.height * scaleY;
    const ctx = canvas.getContext("2d");

    ctx.drawImage(
      image,
      crop.x * scaleX,
      crop.y * scaleY,
      crop.width * scaleX,
      crop.height * scaleY,
      0,
      0,
      crop.width * scaleX,
      crop.height * scaleY
    );

    return new Promise((resolve, reject) => {
      canvas.toBlob((blob) => {
        if (!blob) {
          console.error("Canvas is empty");
          return;
        }
        blob.name = fileName;
        window.URL.revokeObjectURL(this.fileUrl);
        this.fileUrl = window.URL.createObjectURL(blob);
        resolve(this.fileUrl);
      }, "image/jpeg");
    });
  };
